title: Strawberry Line (Yatton to Cheddar) Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Guy Wareham / Strawberry Line
images.caption: Strawberry Line. Looking north along the track, south-west of Sandford.

images.title: FollowMeChaps / The start of the Strawberry Line
images.caption: The start of the Strawberry Line. For almost a century, the 'Strawberry line' carried fruit and passengers from Cheddar over the Mendips and across the Somerset Levels to join the main line at Yatton. Today it has been transformed into a cycle route and footpath which follows the old railway line. This part is maintained by the Yatton & Congresbury Wildlife Action Group

images.title: FollowMeChaps / Congresbury Moor
images.caption: Congresbury Moor. View looking Westwards across the wetland moor taken from the trail.

images.title: Ant Basterfield / The old station at Congresbury
images.caption: The old station. Among the weeds we can just see the old railway station platforms at the former G W R station which is now part of this very popular cycle route that brings bikers and walkers from a large surrounding area. You will note the station sign though not original is more or less a faithful copy.

images.title: Millennium Green Sculpture, Winscombe by Derek Harper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Millennium Green Sculpture, Winscombe

description: This splendid walk and cycle path runs along a former railway line that used to transport strawberries from Cheddar. You start by Yatton railway station and head south passing Congresbury and Axbridge before finishing in Cheddar. The route passes apple orchards, open fields and the River Yeo while there are also pleasant woodland sections at King's Wood and Rose Wood. Also on the route is the delightful Millennium Green at Winscombe (perfect place to stop for lunch!) and the tranquil Cheddar Reservoir at the end of the route. If you have time you could continue up to the magnificent Cheddar Gorge and see this spectacular natural wonder. Axbridge is also well worth exploring with its medieval town square, half timbered buildings and the Tudor King John's Hunting Lodge which houses a fine local museum. The route is part of National Cycle Route 26 which runs from Portishead in Somerset to the Isle of Portland on the south coast of Dorset. You can extend your outing on this signed Sustrans path if you have time.
